column1: Before 1 December 2022, will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States either in Iran or at sea?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'US Politics', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics', 'US Policy']
no
Time decay at this point
#BravoZulu

There have been tensions ongoing between the US and Iran for years. Confrontations have also occurred but a confrontation happening right now before December 1st is highly unlikely. Although there have been tensions, there is no sign of attack or reason for confrontation right now and it will most probably not happen.
This is in my opinion not a 5% probability in the next two days.

I believe that there is a 55% chance that by 1 December 2022 there will be a lethal confrontation between the United States and Iran either in Iran or at sea. According to VOA News, Diplomacy will not stop them (Iran). It is believed that the only thing stopping Iran from escalating conflict is the consequences they would face if they did so. The Intercept states that declining foreign relations with Iran due to the Biden Administration refusing to revive a nuclear deal with Iran. Lastly the South China Morning Post says that Iran was not practicing professional maritime force when they tried to capture an unmanned surface vessel or USV. In conclusion I believe that there is a roughly even chance that there will be a lethal confrontation between Iran and the United Sates military forces either in Iran or at sea before 1 December 2022. This is due to diplomacy will likely not stop Iran from escalating conflict, declining foreign relations between the US and Iran, and Iran's blatant disrespect of professional maritime force.

U.S. relations with Iran have been rocky since the assassination of General Quasem Soleimani 2020, former leader of the Iranian special forces (Who was Qasem Soleimani, the Iranian commander killed by a U.S. airstrike? | CNN). Since Soleimani's death, many attempts on the lives of Americans have been made. One example was the former national security adviser John Bolton. The justice department charged Sharam Poursafi with a plot to kill Bolton. Poursafi sought out American informants offering 300,000 in exchange for the deed (Justice Dept. Charges Iranian in Plot to Kill John Bolton - The New York Times (nytimes.com)). Evidence supports that there were several attempts to attack U.S. soldiers and assets with missile barrages following the death of Soleimani, (Attacks On US Forces In Iraq Since Soleimani's Assassination | MEMRI). This comes with no surprise provided there were early warning detection systems that allowed U.S. personnel to evacuate the area. Islamic resolve against the West and anti-American narratives have always played a role in the situation. Even with the assassination of Soleimani, practical plans to assassinate Americans over there have failed. More assassination attempts will likely be planned but with little success. The likely hood of an attack mounted by the Iranian government succeeding is unlikely due to our early detection systems and the United States' preferring not to engage the Iranian government. Due to our superior detection systems and the United States not wanting to engage in combat with the Iranians, there is a 30% probability that there will be a lethal conflict between the United States and Iran before December 1st.
Inner conflict in Iran, no need to provoke the Mullah regime's outside enemies.
Same rationale as earlier but time has elapsed.

The last few years of Iranian-American relations have been extremely strained due to the 2020 killing of top Iranian general Quasem Soleimani, Commander of the Iranian Special Forces, known as the Quds Force (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-50979463). Iran has vowed to avenge the death of General Soleimani, however, has shown very little effort in revenge (https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/10/us-charges-iranian-of-plot-to-assassinate-john-bolton.html). The Islamic Republic is motivated by traditional radical Islamic and anti-American sentiment, however much like their work in avenging Gen. Soleimani's death, there has been very little concrete steps taken against the US in recent years. Primarily, the Iranians have utilized proxy groups operating in Iraq, Syria, and Yemen to attack US ships and bases (https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/attacks-iran-backed-militias-us-target-are-us-hasnt-responded-force-20-rcna32892). While these attacks are frequent, they are not conducted by the "national military force" of Iran. Additionally, the primary targets of Iranian attacks exist in cyberspace, with the nation mainly targeting US-based businesses and some American infrastructure (https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/iran). Of course, all of these occur in international space, foreign countries, or cyberspace, not in the territory or airspace of the US or Iran. Even despite current high tensions, the conflict between the US and Iran exists in Saudi Arabia, or in Iraq/Syria (https://www.foxnews.com/politics/us-saudi-arabia-high-alert-intel-impending-iranian-attack-report). For these many reasons above, I expect a 25% chance of lethal Iranian-American conflict between conventional national forces before December 1.

While I do have total confidence here, I cannot imagine that this will happen. Iran is busy with its own protesters, the US is busy with Russia and China. Barring an accident or Iran attempting to increase legitimacy by exporting chaos, I do not see this happening. I suspect that Iran will try to clean its own house (ie brutalize its citizens in the name of order) and the US will steer clear, hoping that sanctions and the like will be enough to support its goals.
decrementing down - 22 days until end of period and not seeing much in the news in way of reporting

There have been several attempts on the lives of American citizens since the beginning of this prediction. The US has charged an Iranian man with the attempted assassination of John Bolton, the former US National Security Advisor after being paid $300,000 from Shahram Poursafi, who sought revenge for the death of Iranian General Soleimani. Additionally, there have been several targeted attacks at US personnel from the Iranian government, with early warning systems providing personnel enough time to evacuate the area. However, despite this, the likelihood that there would be a successful attack on US personnel is unlikely as is an attack from the US against Iranian personnel. This stems from the US's early warning systems and preferability to avoid armed conflict with Iran.
They already attempted to attack American persons overseas, with the missile barrage on American bases, with zero casualties, and the attack on the American consulate in Iraq on the 13th of March.
https://www.foxnews.com/politics/us-saudi-arabia-high-alert-intel-impending-iranian-attack-report
Passage of time + short remaining timeframe + very low chance of occurrence during any single day.
@wanderingwolf and @MrLittleTexas good analysis :) - Staying at 5%

No. Neither side has anything to gain from a lethal confrontation. While tensions have been escalating due to the US shooting down Iranian drones inside of Iraq, I believe both sides are in negotiations for a new nuclear deal of some kind. I don't think either side would want to escalate in that way and risk the deal.

There is no incentive and benefit for both Iran and US to conflict In Persian gulf . The previous tension like global hawk aiming and terror of Ghasem soleimani was muted after a while

Seems increasingly unlikely, especially since west needs Iranian oil and gas ASAP.

Biden administration announced it was considering Iranian oil to offset Russia's import loss and despite JCPOA and despite human rights abuses in Iran and despite domestic pressures. This leads me to believe conflict is even less likely.

Returning to 50-50 until further information comes out, then will take another view. Surprised at how low the consensus forecast is on this currently (5%), given that active hostile strikes (even if there were no casualties) have already commenced.
Increasing due to strikes between Iran and Israel. Although my guess is that Israel's main motivation is simply to sabotage the JCPOA.

If the USA is in bed with Iran on an oil deal, the likelihood of conflict is even lower than before.
Sure, why not? The rest of the world is going to hell in a handbasket.

Iran is a military ally for Russia & their key trade partner which means high possibilty to see confrontation in Syria-Ukraine case if Russia asks their support. Also we should consider tension in Syria too.

stranger things have happened.

The US, Iran, and the world, would have no patience for military action this year. While I wouldn't say that I know for sure the US has learned the lesson of "it's not a good idea to fight two foreign wars at once"; I have to imagine the appetite for that has diminished significantly. With the Ukraine tension ongoing ( and possibly exploding into a conflagration), there will be no desire to pursue anything in Iran.
No. Iran is a side show. USA has China and Russia to deal with. USA will get someone else to take on Iran. Iran wants to join the world, so it won't mess that up by messing with USA.
No change.

Iran could take advantage of the Russia-Ukraine distraction, but not likely due to their relationship with Russia. On the other hand, the very same relationship could be used by Russia to cause the USA to be distracted. Keeping my forecast the same.
somebody has to take the fall for WMD terrorist attacks in the West, and we're not prepared for WW3 with Russia quite yet..
Lethal action would probably occur by Iranian back groups, but probably not their official members

Undercutting the crowd slightly on this, but I think that neither party has much motivation for any conflict at the moment. My prediction is based more on the chance of some accidental confrontation happening rather than anything intentional.
Chances of a major conflict seem very low but chances of a minor incident which involves at least one fatality seems significant thought not high in the current and historical context.
With the recent increase of missile attacks from Houthis in Yemen, targeting UAE interests, and Iran's support to Houthis, may be used as a pretext..
This will not happen with Biden regime. This guy won't promote any confrontation with Afghan forces because he is too weak and is secretly partners with the CCP and in turn Iran.

Russia, China, North Korea . . . so on and so on . . . then Iran. . . The current foreign policy priorities of the Biden Administration. If there is a confrontation with Iran this year, it will have be Iran really wanting some national attention, which does not make since for them. Why draw any attention to their continued efforts to build a nuclear bomb?
Over nearly twelve months? With both sides of this proposition playing silly, heavily armed games at each other the chances of one person dying are so high as to be almost certainty.
There is always a chance, but it feels like this is not where attention will be in the next 9 months. Of course that may lead Iran to behave differently. Going with the crowd on a low figure.

i had a hard time even establishing a base rate - when I consider my inside perspective of doing SoH transits - i couldn't immediately recall any prior events that ended with a fatality - they have been confrontations but none lethal that i could find - so right now leaning on the low side
No side could be interested in that.

As Iran continues to push toward high enrichment their potential breakout time to a bomb gets measured in months instead of years. Israel has made it clear that this is a red line for them and is pressuring the US to assist if it decides on military action. Lack of progress in talks and distraction by the US and Russia makes it quite likely that Iran will make significant progress this year. Good article in the New Yorker last month. https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2022/01/03/the-looming-threat-of-a-nuclear-crisis-with-iran

Lowering my forecast significantly given the clarifications in other posts that the confrontation would need to be “between the national military forces…” That lowers the risk quite a bit to something (likely accidental) on the sea or deaths incidental to an air strike. Therefore, while either side might still have motive and opportunity, a conflict situation between the militaries seems low; the more likely possibility is a lethal confrontation involving non-military or Iranian- or US-aligned third parties.

The U.S. and Iran are both focused elsewhere at the moment, but Iran still seeks payback for Soleimani and is seemingly always willing to consider U.S. targets of opportunity. (The Biden administration seems less likely to target Iranian military officials (a la Soleimani) without a more direct provocation.) Nevertheless, the U.S. and Iran are at odds and are both active in multiple conflict zones, making the risk of an undefined lethal confrontation more likely than not.

The world seems to be in some kind of neo-imperialism phase (i.e. Russia and China) or neo-nationalism. I believe that there is a significantly higher possibility of some kind of military conflict between the U.S. and Russia and/or China this year. Not a full-scale war, but some kind of military engagement, probably by proxy. Conflict with Iran is not impossible this year, but with all the other problems emerging in the world and the dovish approach of the Biden Administration, it seems highly unlikely.
Do not see any immediate military confrontation between US and Iran
Not likely.

The complexity of the security environment the Biden administration faces is growing, seemingly on a daily basis. As more adversaries probe for weakness, the risk of conflict with Iran only grows, either deliberate or accidental.

Worrying about IRAN is like worrying about the neighbor's hangnail compared to Russian interventions in the region. In all cases getting involved is nothing more than playground level King of the Hill games. Who has enough wherewithal to throw their weight around and kill off their youth. Remember that War isn't about anything more than population control and rapid destruction of resources to force prices to stay high and convince people that it is necessary that they sacrifice "for the war" while the rich continue to live their lives in high profit and forced lower wages.

We were on the precipice in June 2019, when the Iranians shot down an unmanned aircraft, and September 2019, when they attacked the Saudis, and January 2020, when we took out Sulemani and the Iranians retaliated. There are frequent clashes at sea - July 2021 when a British soldier was killed - and the Houthis sent bombs into the UAE recently, where there are Americans based. And back in the 80s and 90s, there were regulars clashes.
With the deteriorating situation in Ukraine, this becomes less and less likely. The US has learned the hard way becoming engulfed in multiple international conflicts at the same time.
Biden admin has less incentive to be belligerent with Iran.. Iranian hardliners can posture in relation to the ongoing negotiations, without needing a lethal confrontation. That leaves accidents..
I have to imagine with the Ukraine situation that the appetite for even minor military action is very low. I think it will all be via lifting/imposing of sanctions.

Lethal confrontations in recent years have come during periods when the US has disengaged with Iran, and have been at the direction of the Iranian regime. The Biden administration is currently engaged in talks with Iran so legal confrontations are very unlikely. However the Persian Gulf is a busy waterway and accidents can still happen.

The Biden administration will likely take drastic steps to avoid a confrontation with Iran. First, Biden has focused much of his agenda on the economy to the point that he implied that saving the economy was more important than the risk of people spreading omicron in the workplace (although those remarks could be interpreted in a number of ways, WH speech Dec 21, 2021). Further, with his domestic agenda in tatters and ahead of the midterms, the President now needs to focus on the economy to bolster the argument that Dems are capable of governing. At present, 30% of the world's oil is transported through the Strait of Hormuz, and any military confrontation with Iran could lead the country to try and blockade those ships. Yes, the American Navy would like prevail eventually, in the short term, oil prices would rise leading to voters paying more for gas, which has historically been an overemphasized marker of economic success for Americans. Second, the President has shown little appetite for foreign adventures. Biden's experience as the Vice-President overseeing eight years of conflict in Afghanistan seems to have soured him on the prospect of sending in troops. Even as members of his own party called for him to reconsider the Afghanistan pull-out, he went ahead with it and gave a pointed, short speech after the debacle when Kabul fell where he offered no apologies or second thoughts. He was adamant that there was no point in remaining there. Granted, fresh hostilities might, in his mind, create the grounds for a new mission, but I'm going to give the President's mindset significant weight here. Finally, the President faces two other military situations that will likely not go away: Ukraine and Taiwan. Focusing on Iran or committing troops there would likely lead to a broader conflict, bringing in proxy groups and possibly leading Iran to use its missile capabilities to attack the 70k US troops still in the Middle East. The President and US Military leaders--in the face of threats from Russia and China--will likely need all their resources available if either of those situations go hot. I'm giving it 14% still because an accident, miscommunication, or minor incident could possibly lead to at least one death, which the question stipulates.

Could happen with America focused on other threats, Russia and China, but I'm not sure Iran will take the action which will lead to such a confrontation. America is a lot less hawkish on Iran now Trump is no longer President, while Iran has issues at home to deal with. They could use confrontation as a means to distract from said issues, but I don't see it happening any time soon.

The sole exchange directly between US and Iran in the past 3 years resulting in a fatality was the Gen Soleimani strike. The new administration has publicly walked away from the maximum pressure campaign which seems to have driven the escalation resulting in the strike so it is unlikely to repeat. Especially with the attempts to negotiate with Iran on the reentry to JCPOA.

lowering immediately based on crowd forecast. Didn't read question closely enough of National military forces; so any incidental civilian or militia deaths would not count. Also think that the US will pursue this more on economic grounds, they will toy with relieving some sanctions; as I think that is a giant carrot. Military action by Israel would seem more likely (the US could tacitly support those efforts, but that wouldn't satisfy this question.) Leaving forecast higher than crowd still because of Blinken's statements refusing to rule out military action.

I found this one difficult. Neither side ultimately wants any conflict, but they both want diametrically opposite things. At heart are uranium enrichment and sanctions. The sanctions are what exacerbates the whole situation, but it is only the continued enrichment of uranium that will lead to any conflict in my opinion. Throwing in Russia to the mix complicates it further. Russia loves PR victories, especially ones that showcase any role as a mediator. With Russia having an active role in convincing Iran to slow enrichment, they are in the running for a major PR victory. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/1/21/what-next-for-iran-and-russia-ties-after-raisi-putin-meeting. Since the criteria for this question is a single death, that raises the odds; but the American appetite for conflict is very low. OTOH a surgical airstrike elicits much less of a reaction (in the US), and are certainly on the table. The chances that somebody gets killed collaterally in an airstrike on some facility is high. Talks have been happening in Vienna, but awkwardly, Iran and the US only communicate via other European diplomats; so hard to tell how effective they are. Will raise or lower depending on how quickly sanctions on Iran are eased.
I think that Iran will wait until the last minute just before the US launches a military action to sign the nuclear deal
The base rate for any confrontation seems pretty low and the few dust-ups at sea that we've seen have not been lethal. Only 10 months left, really, until this closes.

Rhetoric from Iran remains aggressive and focused on revenge for Soleimani's killing 2 years ago. Since the description in the question stipulates that the Iranian forces must be "national military forces", Iranian-backed Shia Militia Groups in Iraq would not count. So, my forecast is low, despite the rhetoric. I believe they are seeking revenge, but the most likely option is to continue to use semi-attributable means to do so (Shia Militia Groups). In other words, while US service members are at risk in the Middle East, I don't think a direct confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the US is very likely.

Biden would be extremely wary of getting the US embroiled in another war in the Middle East which would at the very least be politically costly. A more limited strike is also unlikely at this time as Biden hopes to coax Iran back to the negotiating table. Iran would be politically obligated to retaliate, and thus could also be potentially costly. On the other hand, if Iran remains totally intransigent and refuses to negotiate, support could build for some sort of action as they get closer to building a working nuclear weapon. Iran uses proxies to carry out destabilizing efforts which fall outside the bounds of this question.
Initial highly subjective forecast.
Iranian general was assassinated by Trump 3 years ago. Probably a one off event but it shows this is far from impossible

Some recent updates: - Iran, China and Russia held their third joint naval drills in the northern Indian Ocean on Friday, state TV reported. - Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi visited Moscow this week accompanied by Iran’s foreign, oil, and economy ministers, in what is seen as a move to strengthen ties with Russia and a turning point in Iranian-Russian relations at a crucial geopolitical moment given the Ukraine situation. Putin had previously complained that Rouhani's government had "preferred to focus on mending relations with the West". "Hard-liners in Tehran—the advocates of a pro-Russia line—now hold all levers of power, and they are evidently determined to deepen relations with the Russians in a host of areas. No Iranian president since 1979 has made such frequent and consistent public calls for strategic ties with Moscow as Raisi. - Putin is working hard not only to build and strengthen alliances but also to put pressure on any sore spots affecting the US and Iran has always been key. - One would think that the war is what is happening now, the high stakes negotiations, the threats, the cyberwarfare, but that no one in the Russia, Iran, China block is seeing an actual physical confrontation. Yet there is a chance of something going wrong when tensions run so high and provocations are escalated to test the opponent.

Certainly, it's in nobody best interest to escalate tensions and the US in particular has hands full with Russian aggression in Ukraine right now so I would expect the US forces in the Middle East to be quite circumspect. That said, Iran may see our distraction with Russia as an opportunity while our attention is elsewhere to probe our reactions; I sense they're comfortable with gamesmanship. So, I weigh those thoughts together at 35% yes.
neither side wants anything more words
I don't think it's any more tense than before.
